attribute.name: account
attribute.description: Charge resources used by this job to specified account.
attribute.tooltip: The account is an arbitrary string. The account name may be changed after job submission using the scontrol command.

attribute.name: begin
attribute.description: Defer the allocation of the job until the specified time.
attribute.tooltip: Submit the batch script to the SLURM controller immediately, like normal, but tell the controller to defer the allocation of the job until the specified time. Time may be of the form HH:MM:SS to run a job at a specific time of day (seconds are optional). (If that time is already past, the next day is assumed.) You may also specify midnight, noon, or teatime (4pm) and you can have a time-of-day suffixed with AM or PM for running in the morning or the evening. You can also say what day the job will be run, by specifying a date of the form MMDDYY or MM/DD/YY or YYYY-MM-DD. Combine date and time using the following format YYYY-MM-DD[HH:MM[:SS]]. You can also give times like "now" + count time-units, where the time-units can be seconds (default), minutes, hours, days, or weeks and you can tell SLURM to run the job today with the keyword "today" and to run the job tomorrow with the keyword "tomorrow". The value may be changed after job submission using the scontrol command.

attribute.name: checkpoint
attribute.description: Specifies the interval between creating checkpoints of the job step.
attribute.tooltip: By default, the job step will have no checkpoints created. Acceptable time formats include "minutes", "minutes:seconds", "hours:minutes:seconds", "days-hours", "days-hours:minutes" and "days-hours:minutes:seconds".

attribute.name: checkpoint_dir
attribute.description: Specifies the directory into which the job or job step's checkpoint should be written.
attribute.tooltip: The default value is the current working directory. Checkpoint files will be of the form "<job_id>.ckpt" for jobs and "<job_id>.<step_id>.ckpt" for job steps.

attribute.name: dependency
attribute.description: Defer the start of this job until the specified dependencies have been satisfied completed.
attribute.tooltip: Format is of the form "type:job_id[:job_id][,type:job_id[:job_id]]. Many jobs can share the same dependency and these jobs may even belong to different users. The value may be changed after job submission using the scontrol command.

attribute.name: workdir
attribute.description: Set the working directory of the batch script to "directory" before it it executed.
attribute.tooltip: Must use absolute path on scheduled system, or "${ptp_rm:directory#value}".

validator.error-message: "workdir" field: Must use absolute path on scheduled system, or "${ptp_rm:directory#value}".

attribute.name: error
attribute.description: Instruct SLURM to connect the batch script's standard error directly to the file name specified in the "filename pattern".
attribute.tooltip: By default both standard output and standard error are directed to a file of the name "slurm-%j.out", where the "%j" is replaced with the job allocation number. See the "--input" option for filename specification options. Use absolute path or "${ptp_rm:workdir#value}" prefix to be relative to working directory.

validator.error-message: "error" field: Use absolute path or "${ptp_rm:workdir#value}" prefix to be relative to working directory.

attribute.name: export
attribute.description: Identify which environment variables are propagated to the batch job.
attribute.tooltip: Format: <environment variables | ALL | NONE >. Multiple environment variable names should be comma separated. Environment variable names may be specified to propagate the current value of those variables (e.g. "--export=EDITOR") or specific values for the variables may be exported (e.g.. "--export=EDITOR=/bin/vi"). This option particularly important for jobs that are submitted on one cluster and execute on a different cluster (e.g. with different paths). By default all environment variables are propagaged. If the argument is NONE or specific environment variable names, then the --get-user-env option will implicitly be set to load other environment variables based upon the user's configuration on the cluster which executes the job.

attribute.name: get_user_env
attribute.description: Tell sbatch to retrieve the login environment variables for the user.
attribute.tooltip: This option will tell sbatch to retrieve the login environment variables for the user specified in the --uid option. The environment variables are retrieved by running something of this sort "su - <username> -c /usr/bin/env" and parsing the output. Be aware that any environment variables already set in sbatch's environment will take precedence over any environment variables in the user's login environment. Clear any environment variables before calling sbatch that you do not want propagated to the spawned program. The optional "timeout" value is in seconds. Default value is 8 seconds. The optional "mode" value control the "su" options. With a "mode" value of "S", "su" is executed without the "-" option. With a "mode" value of "L", "su" is executed with the "-" option, replicating the login environment. If "mode" not specified, the mode established at SLURM build time is used. Example of use include "--get-user-env", "--get-user-env=10" "--get-user-env=10L", and "--get-user-env=S". This option was originally created for use by Moab.

attribute.name: hold
attribute.description: Specify the job is to be submitted in a held state (priority of zero).
attribute.tooltip: A held job can now be released using scontrol to reset its priority (e.g. "scontrol update jobid=<id> priority=1").

attribute.name: immediate
attribute.description: The batch script will only be submitted to the controller if the resources necessary to grant its job allocation are immediately available.
attribute.tooltip: If the job allocation will have to wait in a queue of pending jobs, the batch script will not be submitted.

attribute.name: job_name
attribute.description: Specify a name for the job allocation.
attribute.tooltip: The specified name will appear along with the job id number when querying running jobs on the system. The default is the name of the batch script, or just "sbatch" if the script is read on sbatch's standard input.

validator.error-message: "job_name" field: Must be at least one alphanumeric character

attribute.name: mail_type
attribute.description: Notify user by email when certain event types occur.
attribute.tooltip: Valid type values are BEGIN, END, FAIL, REQUEUE, and ALL (any state change). The user to be notified is indicated with --mail-user.

attribute.name: mail_user
attribute.description: User to receive email notification of state changes.
attribute.tooltip: As defined by --mail-type. The default value is the submitting user.

attribute.name: nodes
attribute.description: Request that a minimum of "minnodes" nodes be allocated to this job.
attribute.tooltip: The scheduler may decide to launch the job on more than "minnodes" nodes. A limit on the maximum node count may be specified with "maxnodes" (e.g. "--nodes=2-4"). The minimum and maximum node count may be the same to specify a specific number of nodes (e.g. "--nodes=2-2" will ask for two and ONLY two nodes). The partition's node limits supersede those of the job. If a job's node limits are outside of the range permitted for its associated partition, the job will be left in a PENDING state. This permits possible execution at a later time, when the partition limit is changed. If a job node limit exceeds the number of nodes configured in the partition, the job will be rejected. Note that the environment variable SLURM_NNODES will be set to the count of nodes actually allocated to the job. See the ENVIRONMENT VARIABLES section for more information. If "-N" is not specified, the default behavior is to allocate enough nodes to satisfy the requirements of the "-n" and "-c" options. The job will be allocated as many nodes as possible within the range specified and without delaying the initiation of the job.

attribute.name: nice
attribute.description: Run the job with an adjusted scheduling priority within SLURM.
attribute.tooltip: With no adjustment value the scheduling priority is decreased by 100. The adjustment range is from -10000 (highest priority) to 10000 (lowest priority). Only privileged users can specify a negative adjustment. NOTE: This option is presently ignored if SchedulerType=sched/wiki or SchedulerType=sched/wiki2.

attribute.name: output
attribute.description: Instruct SLURM to connect the batch script's standard output directly to the file name specified in the "filename pattern".
attribute.tooltip: By default both standard output and standard error are directed to a file of the name "slurm-%j.out", where the "%j" is replaced with the job allocation number. See the --input option for filename specification options. Use absolute path or "${ptp_rm:workdir#value}" prefix to be relative to working directory.

validator.error-message: "output" field: Use absolute path or "${ptp_rm:workdir#value}" prefix to be relative to working directory.

attribute.name: open_mode
attribute.description: Open the output and error files using append or truncate mode as specified.
attribute.tooltip: The default value is specified by the system configuration parameter JobFileAppend.

attribute.name: partition
attribute.description: Request a specific partition for the resource allocation.
attribute.tooltip: If not specified, the default behaviour is to allow the slurm controller to select the default partition as designated by the system administrator. If the job can use more than one partition, specify their names in a comma separate list and the one offering earliest initiation will be used.

attribute.name: quiet
attribute.description: Suppress informational messages from sbatch.
attribute.tooltip: Errors will still be displayed.

attribute.name: reservation
attribute.description: Allocate resources for the job from the named reservation.

attribute.name: signal
attribute.description: When a job is within "sig_time" seconds of its end time, send it the signal "sig_num".
attribute.tooltip: Format: <sig_num>[@<sig_time>]. Due to the resolution of event handling by SLURM, the signal may be sent up to 60 seconds earlier than specified. "sig_num" may either be a signal number or name (e.g. "10" or "USR1"). "sig_time" must have integer value between zero and 65535. By default, no signal is sent before the job's end time. If a "sig_num" is specified without any sig_time, the default time will be 60 seconds.

attribute.name: time
attribute.description: Set a limit on the total run time of the job allocation.
attribute.tooltip: If the requested time limit exceeds the partition's time limit, the job will be left in a PENDING state (possibly indefinitely). The default time limit is the partition's time limit. When the time limit is reached, each task in each job step is sent SIGTERM followed by SIGKILL. The interval between signals is specified by the SLURM configuration parameter "KillWait". A time limit of zero requests that no time limit be imposed. Acceptable time formats include "minutes", "minutes:seconds", "hours:minutes:seconds", "days-hours", "days-hours:minutes" and "days-hours:minutes:seconds".

attribute.name: verbose
attribute.description: Increase the verbosity of sbatch's informational messages.
attribute.tooltip: Multiple -v's will further increase sbatch's verbosity. By default only errors will be displayed.

attribute.name: bgp.cnload_image
attribute.description: Path to compute node image for bluegene block.
attribute.tooltip: BGP only. Default from "blugene.conf" if not set.

attribute.name: bgp.conn_type
attribute.description: Require the partition connection type to be of a certain type.
attribute.tooltip: On Blue Gene the acceptable of "type" are MESH, TORUS and NAV. If NAV, or if not set, then SLURM will try to fit a TORUS else MESH. You should not normally set this option. SLURM will normally allocate a TORUS if possible for a given geometry. If running on a BGP system and wanting to run in HTC mode (only for 1 midplane and below). You can use HTC_S for SMP, HTC_D for Dual, HTC_V for virtual node mode, and HTC_L for Linux mode.

attribute.name: bgp.geometry
attribute.description: Specify the geometry requirements for the job.
attribute.tooltip: The three numbers represent the required geometry giving dimensions in the X, Y and Z directions. For example "--geometry=2x3x4", specifies a block of nodes having 2 x 3 x 4 = 24 nodes (actually base partitions on Blue Gene).

attribute.name: bgp.ioload_image
attribute.description: Path to io image for bluegene block.
attribute.tooltip: BGP only. Default from "blugene.conf" if not set.

attribute.name: bgp.no_rotate
attribute.description: Disables rotation of the job's requested geometry in order to fit an appropriate block.
attribute.tooltip: By default the specified geometry can rotate in three dimensions.

attribute.name: bgp.reboot
attribute.description: Force the allocated nodes to reboot before starting the job.

attribute.name: mpirun.command
attribute.description: Which MPI command to use.

attribute.name: mpirun.np
attribute.description: Number of MPI ranks to use for the job.

attribute.name: mpirun.mode
attribute.description: Execution mode, either SMP, DUAL, or Virtual Node mode.

attribute.name: mpirun.mapfile
attribute.description: "mapfile" contains a user specified MPI topology, or "mapping" is a permutation of XYZT

attribute.name: mpirun.label
attribute.description: Add labels (STDOUT, STDERR, and MPI rank) to the job output.

attribute.name: mpirun.verbose
attribute.description: Verbosity level, default is 0

attribute.name: mpirun.trace
attribute.description: Trace level, output is sent to a file in the current working directory. Default level is 0

attribute.name: mpirun.config
attribute.description: Specify mpirun config file path

browse.title: Browse
browse.tooltip: Clear text box if "Browse" button does not work.

column-data.name: Name
column-data.tooltip: Multi-select and click checkbox to apply change to all rows.

column-data.name: Name
column-data.tooltip: Multi-select and click checkbox to apply change to all rows.
